sections.title: Introduction and Background
sections.tldr: Escherichia coli is a dominant host for recombinant protein production despite challenges like protein misfolding and inclusion body formation. These challenges significantly impact protein yield and functionality, necessitating various strategies to overcome production bottlenecks. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Recombinant protein production represents a foundational platform in biotechnology and biomedicine, with applications spanning from therapeutic proteins to industrial enzymes <Paper corpusId="12023504" paperTitle="(Platas et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264615304" paperTitle="(Ferrer-Miralles et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Among the various host systems available, Escherichia coli remains the predominant choice due to its rapid biomass accumulation, well-established genetic manipulation methods, and straightforward process scale-up <Paper corpusId="1502044" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Despite these advantages, E. coli-based protein production faces significant challenges, with protein misfolding, aggregation, and inclusion body formation being the most prevalent obstacles <Paper corpusId="12023504" paperTitle="(Platas et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="262692133" paperTitle="(Gasser et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper>.

Inclusion bodies (IBs) are dense aggregates of misfolded polypeptides that form when the host cell's protein folding machinery becomes overwhelmed <Paper corpusId="13850343" paperTitle="(Ventura, 2005)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="1502044" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. This phenomenon occurs because the innate E. coli proteostasis network capacity is often insufficient to support the efficient folding of large quantities of a protein-of-interest while simultaneously maintaining the endogenous proteome during bacterial cell growth <Paper corpusId="6380682" paperTitle="(Zhang et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. The formation of inclusion bodies is particularly problematic when proteins are intended for therapeutic uses, as it can compromise both yield and biological activity <Paper corpusId="12023504" paperTitle="(Platas et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="46654714" paperTitle="(Garcia-Fruitos et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

High-level production of recombinant proteins imposes significant stress on the host organism, triggering a heat-shock-like response that involves the induction of chaperones, foldases, and proteases <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. The formation of inclusion bodies has traditionally been viewed as a major bottleneck in protein production processes, necessitating elaborate downstream processing including denaturation and renaturation methods <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264615304" paperTitle="(Ferrer-Miralles et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Typically, inclusion body proteins need to be solubilized using high concentrations of chaotropic agents such as urea and guanidinium chloride before being refolded into their functional state <Paper corpusId="49864461" paperTitle="(Sheli et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Interestingly, recent research has challenged the traditional view that inclusion bodies consist entirely of misfolded and inactive proteins, suggesting that IB-trapped proteins may retain some functionality <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, the formation of inclusion bodies can sometimes be advantageous, as it facilitates initial protein enrichment during purification processes <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Nevertheless, inclusion body formation remains a significant challenge in recombinant protein production, particularly affecting the yield and solubility of the final product.

Understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying protein folding challenges and inclusion body formation is crucial for developing effective strategies to improve recombinant protein production in E. coli <Paper corpusId="12023504" paperTitle="(Platas et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="46654714" paperTitle="(Garcia-Fruitos et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. These mechanisms involve complex interactions between the recombinant protein, the host cell's protein quality control systems, and various environmental factors that influence protein folding and aggregation.

paper.title: Microbial factories for recombinant pharmaceuticals

snippets: Most of the hosts used to produce the 151 recombinant pharmaceuticals so far approved for human use by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and/or by the European Medicines Agency (EMEA) are microbial cells, either bacteria or yeast. This fact indicates that despite the diverse bottlenecks and obstacles that microbial systems pose to the efficient production of functional mammalian proteins, namely lack or unconventional post-translational modifications, proteolytic instability, poor solubility and activation of cell stress responses, among others, they represent convenient and powerful tools for recombinant protein production. The entering into the market of a progressively increasing number of protein drugs produced in non-microbial systems has not impaired the development of products obtained in microbial cells, proving the robustness of the microbial set of cellular systems (so far Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisae) developed for protein drug production. We summarize here the nature, properties and applications of all those pharmaceuticals and the relevant features of the current and potential producing hosts, in a comparative way.

snippets: Escherichia coli retains its dominant position as the first choice of host for the high-throughput production of proteins of therapeutic or commercial interest because of rapid biomass accumulation, well-established genetic manipulation methods and simple process scale-up (Baneyx, 1999)(Swartz, 2001). However, a major disadvantage derived from the intrinsic properties of E. coli is the frequent formation of an inclusion body, a dense aggregate of misfolded polypeptides (Kane et al., 1991). Refolding the inclusion bodies into the native conformation might be straightforward if an efficient refolding scheme is established. There are a variety of conventional methodologies for refolding recombinant proteins from inclusion bodies, which contains simple dilution, dialysis and chromatographic refolding methods. Dilution is the simplest and most widely used technique and involves refolding initiation by reducing the denaturant concentration. However, the target product in dilution refolding can be obtained only very low yield because of protein aggregation at high protein concentration. Column-based refolding is the most likely to renaturate the protein aggregates at high concentration and to reduce the cost for reagents and buffers in largescale protein refolding (Langenhof et al., 2005). Although these conventional methods are commonly used for protein refolding and quite progress has been made, disulfide bond formation and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization have often frustrated the successful refolding of insoluble recombinant proteins containing cysteine and proline in multiple numbers (Clark et al., 1998)(Kiefhaber et al., 1990). Generation of correct disulfide bonds and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans configuration are required processes for formation and stabilization of the native protein conformation. Furthermore, the kinetics and thermodynamics of disulfide bond formation and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization can dominate the rate and pathway of protein folding and in turn determine the refolding efficiency [7](Tan et al., 1997).

snippets: Strong production of recombinant proteins can lead to a stressful situation for the host cell, with the extent of the bacterial stress response being determined by the specific properties of the recombinant protein, and by the rates of transcription and translation [104]. This fact has a clear and profoundly negative impact on productivity and probably protein quality. In addition, recombinant proteins fail, very often, to reach their native conformation when produced in bacteria [105]. This is caused by a coincidence of diverse events impairing protein folding including bottlenecks in transcription and translation, undertitration of chaperones and proteases, improper codon usage and inability of disulfide-bond formation [106,107]. Misfolded protein species usually deposit as amorphous masses of insoluble material called inclusion bodies [108], recorded as by-products of bacterial protein production processes. Inclusion bodies are mainly formed by the deposition of unfolded or partially misfolded protein species that interact through hydrophobic patches unusually exposed to the solvent and with high amino acid sequence homology [109]110].

paper.title: Sequence determinants of protein aggregation: tools to increase protein solubility

snippets: Escherichia coli is one of the most widely used hosts for the production of recombinant proteins. However, very often the target protein accumulates into insoluble aggregates in a misfolded and biologically inactive form. Bacterial inclusion bodies are major bottlenecks in protein production and are hampering the development of top priority research areas such structural genomics. Inclusion body formation was formerly considered to occur via non-specific association of hydrophobic surfaces in folding intermediates. Increasing evidence, however, indicates that protein aggregation in bacteria resembles to the well-studied process of amyloid fibril formation. Both processes appear to rely on the formation of specific, sequence-dependent, intermolecular interactions driving the formation of structured protein aggregates.

paper.title: Analytical approaches for assessing aggregation of protein biopharmaceuticals.

snippets: Production of protein-based pharmaceuticals is a major issue in conventional pharmacology, biomedicine and nanomedicine. Being mostly obtained by genetic engineering, the quality and activity of protein drugs is a steady matter of concern. Although the physiology of the host recombinant cells, mostly mammalian and microbial, is progressively understood, the complexity of the cellular quality control systems escapes rational protein and process engineering, and recombinant proteins are often unstable, aggregate and/or do not reach the fully native conformation compatible with proper biological activity. In this review, we summarize the main biological aspects of protein folding and misfolding, mainly focusing in microbial cells, the newest insights in the biological control of protein quality and the main and analytical approaches that are suitable for the fast evaluation of the conformational quality and aggregation of recombinant drugs, even if showing apparent solubility.

sections.title: Molecular Mechanisms of Inclusion Body Formation
sections.tldr: Inclusion body formation results from protein misfolding due to host microenvironment incompatibility, hydrophobic interactions between partially folded proteins, and overwhelmed cellular folding machinery. These aggregation processes are influenced by protein properties, expression rates, and environmental conditions that create an imbalance between protein production and proper folding. (15 sources)
sections.text:
The formation of inclusion bodies in E. coli is driven by complex molecular mechanisms that occur when the balance between protein production and folding capacity is disrupted. When recombinant genes are expressed in E. coli, the spatio-temporal control of expression is lost, resulting in the synthesis of polypeptides in a microenvironment that may differ significantly from the protein's original source in terms of pH, osmolarity, redox potential, and available cofactors <Paper corpusId="1585460" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This environmental mismatch, coupled with high local concentrations of the nascent heterologous protein, creates conditions conducive to protein misfolding and aggregation.

At the molecular level, inclusion body formation is primarily driven by hydrophobic interactions between partially folded protein intermediates. These intermediates expose hydrophobic patches on their surface that would normally be buried in the properly folded native state <Paper corpusId="221475740" paperTitle="(Sandomenico et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies of recombinant human growth hormone (hGH) have demonstrated that hydrophobic interactions between partially folded amphiphilic and hydrophobic alpha-helices are key determinants of inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="10306518" paperTitle="(Upadhyay et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. These interactions, along with the formation of incorrect disulfide bonds, lead to protein aggregation and precipitation <Paper corpusId="221475740" paperTitle="(Sandomenico et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Inclusion body formation represents an unbalanced equilibrium between protein aggregation and solubilization <Paper corpusId="1585460" paperTitle="(Rosano et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. Under normal physiological conditions, protein folding quality control is maintained by molecular chaperones, folding catalysts, and proteases that monitor and regulate the folding process <Paper corpusId="264496976" paperTitle="(Miot et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. However, during high-level expression of recombinant proteins, these quality control systems become overwhelmed, leading to accumulation of misfolded proteins that either get degraded by proteases, repaired by chaperones, or sequestered as inclusion bodies <Paper corpusId="264496976" paperTitle="(Miot et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="40076667" paperTitle="(Wickner et al., 1999)" isShortName></Paper>.

Two major chaperone systems in E. coli—DnaK-DnaJ-GrpE and GroEL-GroES—play crucial roles in preventing protein aggregation by suppressing off-pathway aggregation reactions and facilitating proper folding through ATP-coordinated cycles of binding and release of folding intermediates <Paper corpusId="35800907" paperTitle="(Mondal et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. These chaperones help accelerate rate-limiting steps in protein folding, such as cis-trans isomerization of peptide-prolyl bonds and formation or reshuffling of disulfide bridges <Paper corpusId="35800907" paperTitle="(Mondal et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

Contrary to earlier assumptions, the formation of inclusion bodies does not correlate with the size of the synthesized polypeptide, the use of fusion constructs, the subunit structure, or the relative hydrophobicity of the recombinant protein <Paper corpusId="112829" paperTitle="(Schumann et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. Rather, overproduction itself—the increase in the concentration of nascent polypeptide chains—can be sufficient to induce inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="112829" paperTitle="(Schumann et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>.

The process of inclusion body formation is dynamic and reversible <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Chaperones involved in aggregate dissociation, including DnaK/DnaJ/ClpB and IbpA/IbpB, co-localize with inclusion bodies in E. coli <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Recent studies have shown that aggregate localization in the cell is not random; small protein aggregates are delivered to a cell pole to form larger structures that can be further dissolved through energy-dependent processes <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

Environmental factors also influence inclusion body formation, including temperature, pH, culture phase, and glucose/oxygen availability <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. The increased temperature and high production rates when using temperature-inducible expression systems, such as λpL/pR-cI857, can alter protein folding and favor protein aggregation <Paper corpusId="469333" paperTitle="(Valdez-Cruz et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="27054322" paperTitle="(Strandberg et al., 1994)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6133280" paperTitle="(Aucoin et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>.

Interestingly, not all inclusion bodies are the same. Traditional inclusion bodies consist primarily of misfolded and inactive proteins, but "non-classical" inclusion bodies have been reported, containing proteins that are soluble, folded, and biologically active <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. This challenges the conventional view that inclusion bodies are merely waste products of protein production processes.

The macromolecular crowding that occurs at high protein concentrations in the E. coli cytoplasm often impairs correct protein folding, leading to the formation of folding intermediates that, when inefficiently processed by molecular chaperones, promote inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="7564064" paperTitle="(Costa et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="112829" paperTitle="(Schumann et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. For cysteine-containing polypeptides, the formation of incorrect disulfide bonds can be a major cause of misfolding and subsequent inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="38377815" paperTitle="(Patil et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="18085151" paperTitle="(Alibolandi et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="35144390" paperTitle="(Sandee et al., 2005)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Protein quality control in the bacterial periplasm

snippets: Although all the information necessary for a protein to reach a native structure is contained in its amino acid sequence, in vivo protein folding requires the participation of protein factors; molecular chaperones, folding catalysts and proteases, that monitor or regulate this process through many cellular functions. Under physiological conditions, these factors maintain quality control of protein biosynthesis, and errors or failures of the protein folding process are rare. However, incorrectly folded or misfolded proteins can appear as a result of (i) spontaneous or inducible mutations that affect protein folding pathways, (ii) exposure of the cell to environmental stress, such as elevated temperatures or hyperosmolarity, and (iii) overexpression of recombinant genes. In these cases, the polypeptide chain, instead of folding into the native biologically active state, misfolds, and eventually induces a stress response (Goff et al., 1985). The resulting misfolded proteins may either be degraded by proteases, repaired by chaperones, or aggregated and sequestered as inclusion bodies (IBs), when escaping protein folding quality control (Wickner et al., 1999).

paper.title: Posttranslational quality control: folding, refolding, and degrading proteins.

snippets: Polypeptides emerging from the ribosome must fold into stable three-dimensional structures and maintain that structure throughout their functional lifetimes. Maintaining quality control over protein structure and function depends on molecular chaperones and proteases, both of which can recognize hydrophobic regions exposed on unfolded polypeptides. Molecular chaperones promote proper protein folding and prevent aggregation, and energy-dependent proteases eliminate irreversibly damaged proteins. The kinetics of partitioning between chaperones and proteases determines whether a protein will be destroyed before it folds properly. When both quality control options fail, damaged proteins accumulate as aggregates, a process associated with amyloid diseases.

paper.title: Production of recombinant proteins in Escherichia coli

snippets:
Rapid production of recombinant proteins can lead to the formation of insoluble aggregates designated as inclusion bodies (Betts et al., 1999). These are large, spherical particles which are clearly separated from the cytoplasm and result from the failure of the quality control system to repair or remove misfolded or unfolded protein. 

The formation of inclusion bodies does not correlate with (1) the size of the synthesized polypeptide, (2) the use of the fusion construct, (3) the subunit structure and (4) the relative hydrophobicity of the recombinant protein. Overproduction by itself (the increase in the concentration of the nascent polypeptide chains) can be sufficient to induce the formation of inclusion bodies. These aggregates do not consist of pure recombinant polypeptide chains, but contain several impurities such as host proteins (RNA polymerase, outer membrane proteins), ribosomal components and circular and nicked forms of plasmid DNA. In addition, they might contain the small heat shock proteins IbpA and IbpB. Strategies to prevent the formation of inclusion bodies are aimed to slow down the production of recombinant proteins and include (1) low-copy number vectors, (2) weak promoters, (3) low temperature, (4) coexpression of molecular chaperones, (5) use of a solubilizing partner, and (6) fermentation at extreme pH values.

snippets:
When heterologous recombinant proteins are produced in Escherichia coli, they often precipitate to form insoluble aggregates of unfolded polypeptides called inclusion bodies. These structures are associated with chaperones like IbpA. However, there are reported cases of "non-classical" inclusion bodies in which proteins are soluble, folded and active.

IB formation results from the aggregation of misfolded polypeptides that have escaped quality control by chaperones and proteases to interact through their exposed hydrophobic regions before precipitating [3]. Aggregate formation and features are influenced by various growth conditions such as temperature and pH [4], culture phase [5] and glucose/oxygen availability [6].

In vivo protein aggregation is a dynamic reversible process [7]. Chaperones involved in aggregate dissociation, e.g. DnaK/DnaJ/ClpB and IbpA/IbpB, colocalize with IB in E. coli [8][9][10][11]. Recently, it has been reported that aggregate cellular localization is not random [9]. Small protein aggregates are delivered to a cell pole to form larger structures that are further dissolved by an energy dependent process [12]. All proteins in IB were initially considered as unfolded, but it has been shown that some polypeptides inside aggregates are present in an active form [2,13,14]. Several groups reported the formation of "non-classical" IB mainly characterized by the presence of folded and soluble recombinant proteins [15]16].

snippets: BackgroundIn the interest of generating large amounts of recombinant protein, inducible systems have been studied to maximize both the growth of the culture and the production of foreign proteins. Even though thermo-inducible systems were developed in the late 1970's, the number of studies that focus on strategies for the implementation at bioreactor scale is limited. In this work, the bacteriophage lambda PL promoter is once again investigated as an inducible element but for the production of green fluorescent protein (GFP). Culture temperature, induction point, induction duration and number of inductions were considered as factors to maximize GFP production in a 20-L bioreactor.ResultsIt was found that cultures carried out at 37°C resulted in a growth-associated production of GFP without the need of an induction at 42°C. Specific production was similar to what was achieved when separating the growth and production phases. Shake flask cultures were used to screen for desirable operating conditions. It was found that multiple inductions increased the production of GFP. Induction decreased the growth rate and substrate yield coefficients; therefore, two time domains (before and after induction) having different kinetic parameters were created to fit a model to the data collected.ConclusionBased on two batch runs and the simulation of culture dynamics, a pre-defined feeding and induction strategy was developed to increase the volumetric yield of a temperature regulated expression system and was successfully implemented in a 20-L bioreactor. An overall cell density of 5.95 g DW l-1 was achieved without detriment to the cell specific production of GFP; however, the production of GFP was underestimated in the simulations due to a significant contribution of non-growth associated product formation under limiting nutrient conditions.

snippets: A major challenge in obtaining a recombinant protein is correct folding. A protein synthesized in a recombinant cell is often produced in reduced form, which is then oxidized (refolded) using suitable folding conditions (Clark, 1998)(Rudolph et al., 1996). The target crude peptide/protein can be obtained in reduced form and then refolded with the aid of various enzymes as disulfide catalyst systems [95](키스톤 et al., 1985). Alternatively, oxidative folding is possible without the use of any enzyme (Freedman, 1995)(Frand et al., 2000). However, such refolding can be a problematic step. Misfolding is a major issue with cysteine-containing polypeptides resulting in low yields. This limitation has necessitated the development of new methodologies to enable the acquisition of correctly folded protein or peptide in its native form in high yields. To assist the refolding, various tactics have been employed including inclusion body formation (Luan et al., 2014)(Alibolandi et al., 2011), co-expression of supporting enzymes (Sandee et al., 2005)(Kondo et al., 2000) and chemical assistance (Alibolandi et al., 2011).

paper.title: Chemical Assistance in Refolding of Bacterial Inclusion Bodies

snippets: Escherichia coli is one of the most widely used hosts for the production of recombinant proteins but insoluble expression of heterologous proteins is a major bottleneck in production of recombinant proteins in E. coli. In vitro refolding of inclusion body into proteins with native conformations is a solution for this problem but there is a need for optimization of condition for each protein specifically. Several approaches have been described for in vitro refolding; most of them involve the use of additives for assisting correct folding. Cosolutes play a major role in refolding process and can be classified according to their function as aggregation suppressors and folding enhancers. sections.title: Cellular Factors Affecting Protein Folding
sections.tldr: Protein folding in E. coli is influenced by the host's limited folding machinery, reducing cytoplasmic environment, and overwhelmed quality control systems during recombinant overexpression. Factors such as inducer concentration, chaperone availability, and disulfide bond formation capabilities critically impact protein solubility, with significant implications for biotechnological applications. sections.text:
The successful production of soluble, correctly folded recombinant proteins in E. coli is constrained by several cellular factors that influence protein folding and aggregation. One major limitation is E. coli's relatively simple protein folding machinery, which lacks the sophisticated post-translational modification capabilities found in eukaryotic systems <Paper corpusId="31546198" paperTitle="(Francis et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. This becomes particularly problematic when expressing complex eukaryotic proteins that require longer folding times or specific chaperones to reach their native state <Paper corpusId="31546198" paperTitle="(Francis et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

The cytoplasmic redox environment of E. coli presents another significant challenge. The bacterial cytoplasm is highly reductive due to the presence of thioredoxin and glutaredoxin systems, which effectively reduce disulfide bonds back to free thiols <Paper corpusId="272055653" paperTitle="(Solowinska et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This reducing environment is particularly problematic for recombinant proteins requiring disulfide bonds for structural stability, as these bonds are essential for proper folding and functionality in many eukaryotic proteins <Paper corpusId="272055653" paperTitle="(Solowinska et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="34983770" paperTitle="(Scheiblhofer et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. The complexity of achieving native conformations increases proportionally with the number of cysteine residues due to the various possible disulfide bond patterns <Paper corpusId="272055653" paperTitle="(Solowinska et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

E. coli's protein quality control system, comprising molecular chaperones, folding catalysts, and proteases, becomes overwhelmed during high-level expression of recombinant proteins <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5803739" paperTitle="(Schrodel et al., 2005)" isShortName></Paper>. Molecular chaperones play crucial roles in preventing aggregation by binding exposed hydrophobic regions in unfolded or partially folded polypeptides, while folding catalysts facilitate rate-limiting steps such as peptidyl bond isomerization or disulfide bond formation <Paper corpusId="15379654" paperTitle="(Kolaj et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. However, when recombinant proteins are overexpressed, the limited capacity of these systems can lead to protein misfolding and aggregation <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>.

The expression rate also significantly influences protein folding outcomes. High expression rates driven by strong promoters or high inducer concentrations can overwhelm the cell's folding machinery, leading to increased inclusion body formation <Paper corpusId="272645465" paperTitle="(Kuri et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Finding the optimal inducer concentration is crucial, as too high concentrations may cause cellular stress and protein aggregation, while too low concentrations may result in insufficient protein production <Paper corpusId="272645465" paperTitle="(Kuri et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Interestingly, recombinant protein overexpression has been shown to induce significant physiological changes in E. coli, including a stress response similar to heat shock <Paper corpusId="7172234" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="1336325" paperTitle="(Parsell et al., 1989)" isShortName></Paper>. This response leads to altered expression patterns of cytosolic chaperones and proteases compared to host cells without recombinant protein expression <Paper corpusId="7172234" paperTitle="(Cheng et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. The presence of unfolded proteins in the cell has been identified as a signal that triggers this heat shock-like response <Paper corpusId="1336325" paperTitle="(Parsell et al., 1989)" isShortName></Paper>.

Various strategies have been developed to address these cellular limitations, including co-expression of chaperones, use of fusion tags, selection of appropriate host strains and promoter systems, and optimization of cultivation conditions <Paper corpusId="18153843" paperTitle="(Peternel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>. Coordinated overproduction of multiple chaperone systems, such as GroEL/GroES, DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE, ClpB, and small heat shock proteins IbpA/IbpB, has shown promising results in enhancing protein solubility <Paper corpusId="18153843" paperTitle="(Peternel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advancements, it's important to note that protein solubility does not always correlate with biological activity <Paper corpusId="18153843" paperTitle="(Peternel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that a significant proportion of proteins found soluble in the cytoplasm can be biologically inactive <Paper corpusId="18153843" paperTitle="(Peternel et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. This highlights the complex relationship between protein solubility, folding, and functionality in recombinant expression systems.

snippets: BackgroundThe first aim of the work was to analyze in detail the complexity of the aggregates formed upon overexpression of recombinant proteins in E. coli. A sucrose step gradient succeeded in separating aggregate subclasses of a GFP-GST fusion protein with specific biochemical and biophysical features, providing a novel approach for studying recombinant protein aggregates.ResultsThe total lysate separated into 4 different fractions whereas only the one with the lowest density was detected when the supernatant recovered after ultracentrifugation was loaded onto the sucrose gradient. The three further aggregate sub-classes were otherwise indistinctly precipitated in the pellet. The distribution of the recombinant protein among the four subclasses was strongly dependent on the DnaK availability, with larger aggregates formed in Dnak- mutants. The aggregation state of the GFP-GST recovered from each of the four fractions was further characterized by examining three independent biochemical parameters. All of them showed an increased complexity of the recombinant protein aggregates starting from the top of the sucrose gradient (lower mass aggregates) to the bottom (larger mass aggregates). These results were also confirmed by electron microscopy analysis of the macro-structure formed by the different aggregates. Large fibrils were rapidly assembled when the recombinant protein was incubated in the presence of cellular extracts, but the GFP-GST fusion purified soon after lysis failed to undergo amyloidation, indicating that other cell components probably participate in the active formation of large aggregates. Finally, we showed that aggregates of lower complexity are more efficiently disaggregated by a combination of molecular chaperones.ConclusionAn additional analytical tool is now available to investigate the aggregation process and separate subclasses by their mass. It was possible to demonstrate the complexity of the aggregation pattern of a recombinant protein expressed in bacteria and to characterize biochemically the different aggregate subclasses. Furthermore, we have obtained evidence that the cellular environment plays a role in the development of the aggregates and the problem of the artifact generation of aggregates has been discussed using in vitro models. Finally, the possibility of separating aggregate fractions with different complexities offers new options for biotechnological strategies aimed at improving the yield of folded and active recombinant proteins.

However, it is now known that protein aggregation into IBs is reversible [26] and dependent on the physiological state of the host organism. sections.title: Composition and Properties of Inclusion Bodies
sections.tldr: Inclusion bodies (IBs) are dense protein aggregates formed during recombinant protein production in E. coli, consisting predominantly of the overexpressed protein in various conformational states. These dynamic structures can range from completely inactive aggregates to "non-classical" IBs containing biologically active proteins, with their properties being influenced by production conditions. sections.text:
Inclusion bodies (IBs) are insoluble protein aggregates that form in the cytoplasm of E. coli during high-level recombinant protein production. These structures typically range in size from 0.1 to 1 μm and preferentially localize at the bacterial cell poles, which is thought to be related to the accumulation of dense DNA in the central region of the cells <Paper corpusId="210117266" paperTitle="(Jong et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. While their chemical composition may vary, IBs consist predominantly of the overexpressed recombinant protein <Paper corpusId="210117266" paperTitle="(Jong et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="53030068" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Contrary to traditional views that considered IBs as simple deposits of inactive misfolded proteins, recent studies have revealed that these structures are complex and dynamic entities <Paper corpusId="248099359" paperTitle="(Restrepo-Pineda et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. In fact, IBs can harbor proteins in different conformational states, including partially or even fully native structures <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="14342389" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. This finding has led to a paradigm shift in understanding IBs, with researchers now recognizing that a whole spectrum of polypeptide conformations can exist within these aggregates <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

Interestingly, IBs have been found to contain an amorphous matrix that fills the spaces between and inside the protein aggregates, potentially allowing the diffusion of reactants <Paper corpusId="32093151" paperTitle="(Rehm et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. This structural characteristic might explain why some IBs can retain biological activity despite their aggregated state. Several studies have reported cases of "non-classical" inclusion bodies in which proteins remain soluble, folded, and active <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. These findings challenge the conventional view that IBs are merely waste products of protein production processes.

The properties of IBs are significantly influenced by various factors, including production conditions such as temperature, pH, culture phase, and glucose/oxygen availability <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. These conditions affect not only the formation of IBs but also the conformational states of the proteins within them, which in turn impacts protein recovery and solubilization strategies <Paper corpusId="248099359" paperTitle="(Restrepo-Pineda et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Protein aggregation in IBs is now understood to be a dynamic and reversible process <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Molecular chaperones involved in aggregate dissociation, such as DnaK/DnaJ/ClpB and IbpA/IbpB, co-localize with IBs in E. coli cells <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. Recent research has shown that aggregate localization in the cell is not random; small protein aggregates are delivered to a cell pole to form larger structures that can be further dissolved through energy-dependent processes <Paper corpusId="5168964" paperTitle="(Henst et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

While the formation of IBs was traditionally viewed as an obstacle in protein production processes, this perspective has evolved. In some cases, insoluble but active proteins sequestered in IBs can be the preferred form of the product <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Currently, quite a number of recombinant products are intentionally produced as IBs, which are then processed to yield correctly folded and soluble products <Paper corpusId="53008768" paperTitle="(Humer et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach provides an easy method for protein isolation and purification, although the subsequent refolding of the recombinant protein in vitro to gain biological activity can present significant challenges <Paper corpusId="5682245" paperTitle="(Kong et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advances in understanding, the formation of IBs in E. coli remains complex, and the exact mechanisms are not yet fully elucidated <Paper corpusId="5682245" paperTitle="(Kong et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Some eukaryotic proteins have a high propensity to aggregate regardless of the type of fusion tag used to improve protein solubility, leading to challenging procedures for in vitro refolding <Paper corpusId="5682245" paperTitle="(Kong et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: Heterologous proteins that are overexpressed in microbial hosts such as E. coli often accumulate in insoluble clusters called inclusion bodies (IBs). The IBs preferentially localize at the poles of the bacteria, which is thought to be related to the accumulation of dense DNA central in the cells. The IBs vary in size from 0.1 to 1 µm and although their chemical composition may vary, they consist predominantly of the overexpressed recombinant protein (Ramon et al., 2014;(Marco et al., 2018). Traditionally, IB formation is linked to the aggregation of misfolded polypeptides and seen as an obstacle in production processes aimed at high yields of soluble, active protein species. To avoid aggregation several strategies have been explored including lowering of transcription and translation rates, reduction of the growth temperature and co-expression of chaperones that assist in proper folding (Kaur et al., 2018).

paper.title: Bacterial inclusion bodies are industrially exploitable amyloids

snippets: Understanding the structure, functionalities and biology of functional amyloids is an issue of emerging interest. Inclusion bodies, namely protein clusters formed in recombinant bacteria during protein production processes, have emerged as unanticipated, highly tunable models for the scrutiny of the physiology and architecture of functional amyloids. Based on an amyloidal skeleton combined with varying amounts of native or native-like protein forms, bacterial inclusion bodies exhibit an unusual arrangement that confers mechanical stability, biological activity and conditional protein release, being thus exploitable as versatile biomaterials. The applicability of inclusion bodies in biotechnology as enriched sources of protein and reusable catalysts, and in biomedicine as biocompatible topographies, nanopills or mimetics of endocrine secretory granules has been largely validated. Beyond these uses, the dissection of how recombinant bacteria manage the aggregation of functional protein species into structures of highly variable complexity offers insights about unsuspected connections between protein quality (conformational status compatible with functionality) and cell physiology.

sections.title: Impact on Yield and Solubility
sections.tldr: Inclusion body formation significantly reduces recombinant protein yields and functional activity in E. coli, requiring costly downstream processing for protein recovery. This aggregation negatively impacts both host cell viability and overall production economics, making it a major bottleneck in industrial protein manufacturing. (8 sources)
sections.text:
The formation of inclusion bodies represents a significant impediment to achieving high yields of soluble, functional recombinant proteins in E. coli expression systems. When proteins aggregate into inclusion bodies, the effective yield of biologically active product is substantially reduced, necessitating elaborate downstream processing to recover functional proteins <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. This recovery typically involves denaturation using chaotropic agents followed by refolding procedures, which are not only time-consuming but also costly and often result in considerable product loss <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2746892" paperTitle="(Chan et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

The economic impact of inclusion body formation on recombinant protein production is substantial. The recovery of active proteins from inclusion bodies can lead to tremendous loss of product during extraction and refolding processes, significantly reducing the total yield of biologically active recombinant proteins <Paper corpusId="196660066" paperTitle="(Al-hejin et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Although inclusion bodies provide an easy method for initial protein isolation and purification, the subsequent in vitro refolding to gain biological activity often presents great challenges that can compromise overall process efficiency <Paper corpusId="5682245" paperTitle="(Kong et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

Beyond yield reduction, protein aggregation also affects host cell physiology and viability. Inclusion body formation is generally harmful to the host through increased cellular metabolic burden and intermolecular interactions with other cellular components, which can reduce cell viability and further decrease overall production yield <Paper corpusId="195772930" paperTitle="(Bui et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, recombinant protein precipitation due to improper folding or aggregation not only decreases production yield but also alters gene transcription patterns in the E. coli strain, potentially creating cascading effects on cellular metabolism <Paper corpusId="235487030" paperTitle="(Terol et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

While traditional inclusion bodies contain misfolded and inactive proteins, it's worth noting that recent research has challenged this view, showing that some inclusion body-trapped proteins may retain functionality <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="264615304" paperTitle="(Ferrer-Miralles et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. Nevertheless, even in these cases, further processing is still required to achieve soluble protein products, adding complexity and cost to the production process <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

Rapid production of recombinant proteins can lead to the formation of insoluble aggregates designated as inclusion bodies (Betts et al., 1999). snippets: Formation of inclusion bodies in bacterial hosts poses a major challenge for large scale recovery of bioactive proteins. These methods solubilize the inclusion body aggregates while preserving the native-like protein structure. Subsequent protein refolding and purification results in high recovery of bioactive protein. Other parameters which influence the overall recovery of bioactive protein from inclusion bodies have also been discussed. A schematic model describing the utility of mild solubilization methods for high throughput recovery of bioactive protein has also been presented.

sections.text:
The recovery of biologically active proteins from inclusion bodies (IBs) represents a critical challenge in recombinant protein production processes. When proteins aggregate as IBs, additional downstream processing steps become necessary, including solubilization of the aggregates and subsequent refolding procedures to recover functional proteins <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. These processes are typically time-consuming, laborious, and expensive, particularly for multidomain and disulfide-rich proteins <Paper corpusId="24530886" paperTitle="(Sharma et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

Conventional methodologies for refolding proteins from inclusion bodies include simple dilution, dialysis, and chromatographic refolding methods. Dilution, while the simplest and most widely used technique, typically yields low amounts of active protein due to reaggregation at high protein concentrations. Column-based refolding methods are more promising for refolding protein aggregates at higher concentrations and can reduce costs for reagents and buffers in large-scale operations <Paper corpusId="1502044" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

Proteins containing multiple cysteine and proline residues present particular challenges during refolding. The formation of correct disulfide bonds and proper peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization are essential for achieving native protein conformation and can significantly influence both the rate and pathway of protein folding <Paper corpusId="1502044" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2003077" paperTitle="(Tan et al., 1997)" isShortName></Paper>. For disulfide-rich proteins, such as antimicrobial peptides and human serum albumin, recovery of functional protein from inclusion bodies is particularly difficult due to the complexity of achieving correct disulfide bond patterns <Paper corpusId="203651627" paperTitle="(Eichmann et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="24530886" paperTitle="(Sharma et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="7394558" paperTitle="(Lawn et al., 1981)" isShortName></Paper>.

The traditional process typically involves solubilization using high concentrations of chaotropic agents such as urea and guanidinium chloride, followed by refolding procedures to achieve the native protein conformation <Paper corpusId="49864461" paperTitle="(Sheli et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. While this approach has been considered a bottleneck in protein production, perspectives have evolved. Currently, many recombinant products are intentionally produced as inclusion bodies, which are then processed to yield correctly folded and soluble products <Paper corpusId="53008768" paperTitle="(Humer et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent research has revealed that inclusion bodies may contain a spectrum of protein conformations, including partially or even fully native structures <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="14342389" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>. This finding has important implications for protein recovery strategies, as it suggests that some IBs may already contain proteins with significant biological activity. Indeed, studies have demonstrated that inclusion bodies containing small heat shock proteins IbpA/B can preserve higher enzymatic activity compared to IbpA/B-deficient aggregates <Paper corpusId="14342389" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2004)" isShortName></Paper>.

To improve the efficiency of protein recovery from inclusion bodies, advanced strategies have been developed. A particularly effective approach is the two-step chaperone co-expression procedure, which has shown remarkable success in increasing protein solubility. In this method, chaperone systems are first co-expressed with the recombinant protein to optimize de novo folding, followed by inhibition of protein biosynthesis to allow chaperone-mediated refolding of misfolded and aggregated proteins in vivo <Paper corpusId="10684903" paperTitle="(Kuczynska-Wisnik et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6392822" paperTitle="(Marco et al., 2007)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advances, the recovery of functional proteins from inclusion bodies remains challenging, particularly for complex eukaryotic proteins expressed in E. coli. The efficiency of refolding processes is influenced by numerous factors, including the properties of the protein itself, the composition of the inclusion bodies, and the specific refolding conditions employed <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">.

Coexpression of molecular chaperones or lower production rate can prevent aggregation and facilitate the proper folding of recombinant proteins (Rosano et al., 2014)(Schlieker et al., 2002)(Marco et al., 2007). A whole spectrum of polypeptides with different conformations, including partially or even fully native structures, can be found in IBs (Kuczyńska-Wiśnik et al., 2004)(Garcia-Fruitós et al., 2006)[6]. Therefore, in some cases, insoluble but active proteins sequestered in IBs can be the preferred form of the product (Hrabárová et al., 2015).

paper.title: Folding machineries displayed on a cation-exchanger for the concerted refolding of cysteine- or proline-rich proteins

snippets: Escherichia coli retains its dominant position as the first choice of host for the high-throughput production of proteins of therapeutic or commercial interest because of rapid biomass accumulation, well-established genetic manipulation methods and simple process scale-up (Baneyx, 1999)(Swartz, 2001). However, a major disadvantage derived from the intrinsic properties of E. coli is the frequent formation of an inclusion body, a dense aggregate of misfolded polypeptides (Kane et al., 1991). Refolding the inclusion bodies into the native conformation might be straightforward if an efficient refolding scheme is established. There are a variety of conventional methodologies for refolding recombinant proteins from inclusion bodies, which contains simple dilution, dialysis and chromatographic refolding methods. Dilution is the simplest and most widely used technique and involves refolding initiation by reducing the denaturant concentration. However, the target product in dilution refolding can be obtained only very low yield because of protein aggregation at high protein concentration. Column-based refolding is the most likely to renaturate the protein aggregates at high concentration and to reduce the cost for reagents and buffers in largescale protein refolding (Langenhof et al., 2005). Although these conventional methods are commonly used for protein refolding and quite progress has been made, disulfide bond formation and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization have often frustrated the successful refolding of insoluble recombinant proteins containing cysteine and proline in multiple numbers (Clark et al., 1998)(Kiefhaber et al., 1990). Generation of correct disulfide bonds and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans configuration are required processes for formation and stabilization of the native protein conformation. Furthermore, the kinetics and thermodynamics of disulfide bond formation and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization can dominate the rate and pathway of protein folding and in turn determine the refolding efficiency [7](Tan et al., 1997).

paper.title: The rate of isomerisation of peptidyl-proline bonds as a probe for interactions in the physiological denatured state of chymotrypsin inhibitor 2.

snippets: There are four peptidyl-proline bonds in the 64-residue protein chymotrypsin inhibitor 2 (CI2), all of which are in the trans conformation in the native structure. The isomerisation of one or more of these peptidyl-proline bonds to the cis conformation in the denatured state gives rise to heterogeneity, leading to both fast and slow-folding species. The refolding of the fast-folding species, which has all trans peptidyl-proline bonds, is much faster than that of the slow-folding species, which have one or more cis peptidyl-proline bonds. In CI2, the slow-folding species can be classified into two groups by their rates of refolding, temperature-dependence, pH-dependence and [GdmCl]-dependence of the rate constants and the effect of peptidyl-prolyl isomerase on the rate constants. The replacement of Pro6 by Ala removes one of the slow refolding phases, suggesting that the cis peptidyl-Pro6 conformation is solely responsible for one of the slow-folding species. Pro6 is located in a region of the protein where non-random interactions have been found in a series of N-terminal fragments of CI2 (residues 1 to 13, 1 to 25, 1 to 28 and 1 to 40). In addition, NMR studies on a mutant fragment, (1-40)T3A, have confirmed that this non-native interaction is associated with the bulky side-chain of Trp5. The atypical rate of cis to trans isomerisation of the peptidyl-Pro bond is indicative of the presence of a similar hydrophobic cluster in the physiological denatured state of intact CI2.

snippets: Although, many recombinant proteins are strongly expressed with short production times and can be recovered as soluble products, others are difficult to express either because they are toxic to the host, resulting in low yields, or because they form insoluble inclusion bodies due to incomplete or incorrect folding (Carrio et al., 2002)(Saïda, 2007). paper.title: Structural characterization of recombinant streptokinase following recovery from inclusion bodies using different chemical solubilization treatments

snippets: Escherichia coli (E. coli) has been used as an integral host for production of recombinant proteins in biopharmaceutical industry; however, production of recombinant proteins in E. coli has been associated with serious challenges. One major part of challenges is related to the fact that the overexpression of recombinant proteins in E. coli often leads to the formation of misfolded protein aggregates, called inclusion bodies (IBs), mainly because of differences in folding pathways and physicochemical conditions between expression and natural hosts (Wyre et al., 2014). Although recombinant protein production via inclusion body formation system looks attractive due to attributes such as relatively straightforward IB generation to high yields, good supply of soluble protein after applying a solubilization treatment and potential clear-cut purification of target protein to high purities, IB proteins mostly contain non-functional target proteins which need to be solubilized by denaturants (e.g., high concentrations of chaotropic agents including urea and guanidinium chloride) and then refolded to functional (bioactive) counterparts (Overton, 2014)[3].

paper.title: Escherichia coli small heat shock proteins IbpA/B enhance activity of enzymes sequestered in inclusion bodies.

snippets: Escherichia coli small heat shock proteins, IbpA/B, function as molecular chaperones and protect misfolded proteins against irreversible aggregation. IbpA/B are induced during overproduction of recombinant proteins and bind to inclusion bodies in E. coli cells. We investigated the effect of DeltaibpA/B mutation on formation of inclusion bodies and biological activity of enzymes sequestered in the aggregates in E. coli cells. Using three different recombinant proteins: Cro-beta-galactosidase, beta-lactamase and rat rHtrA1 we demonstrated that deletion of the ibpA/B operon did not affect the level of produced inclusion bodies. However, in aggregates containing IbpA/B a higher enzymatic activity was detected than in the IbpA/B-deficient inclusion bodies. These results confirm that IbpA/B protect misfolded proteins from inactivation in vivo.
